Synthesis and characterization of acetic acid functionalized poly (4-vinylpyridinium) salt as new catalyst for the synthesis of spiropyran derivatives and their biological activity Ahmad Reza Moosavi-Zare a ⁎ Mohammad Ali Zolfigol b Ehsan Noroozizadeh b Mahmoud Zarei b Roya Karamian c Mostafa Asadbegy c a University of Sayyed Jamaleddin Asadabadi, Asadabad, 6541835583, Islamic Republic of Iran University of Sayyed Jamaleddin Asadabadi Asadabad 6541835583 Islamic Republic of Iran b Faculty of Chemistry, Bu-Ali Sina University, Hamedan 6517838683, Islamic Republic of Iran Faculty of Chemistry Bu-Ali Sina University Hamedan 6517838683 Islamic Republic of Iran c Department of Biology, Faculty of Science, Bu-Ali Sina University, P. O. Box 65175/4161, Hamedan, Islamic Republic of Iran Department of Biology Faculty of Science Bu-Ali Sina University P. O. Box 65175/4161 Hamedan Islamic Republic of Iran ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Acetic acid functionalized poly(4-vinylpyridinium) bromide (APVPB), as a new and heterogeneous catalyst, was designed and successfully tested on the synthesis of 2-aminospiro[indoline-3,4ʹpyran]-2-one and spiro[indeno[1,2-b]quinoxaline-11,4-pyran]-2ʹ-amine derivatives. Also, infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA), differential thermal gravimetric (DTG), scanning electron microscope (SEM), X-ray diffraction analysis (XRD) and energy dispersive X-ray analysis (EDX) of the catalyst has been studied in the presented work. The prepared spiro-pyrans were solved in DMSO and subjected to antioxidant activity screening by DPPH free radical scavenging assay and antifungal activity against Fusarium oxysporum. Results showed that the synthesized spiro-pyran possess strong antioxidant activity (IC50; 0.161±0.009 to 1.509±0.007mg/ml) and also good inhibition activity against Fusarium oxysporum (65.8±1.4% to 88.3±2.2% at 500 ppm concentration and 89.2±3.2% to 100±0.0% at 1000ppm concentration). For their biological activities, the prepared spiro-pyran compounds may be suggested to apply as alternative systems in medicine and agriculture. Keywords Acetic acid functionalized poly(4-vinylpyridinium) bromide (AFPVPB) Heterogeneous catalyst 2-amino spiro[indoline-3,4′pyran]-2-one Spiro [indeno[1,2-b]quinoxaline-11,4-pyran]-2′-amine Antioxidant Antifungal 1 Introduction During the last decade multi component reactions (MCRs) have been attracted the attention of organic chemists for combinatorial chemistry in toward the prepare target compounds including heterocyclics scaffold with a significant role in biologically activity, greater efficiency and atomic economy by generating in a single step from three or more reactants. Also, MCRs offer some advantages such as simplicity and synthetic efficiency over conventional chemical reactions [1–5]. Free radical such as reactive oxygen or nitrogen species (ROS or RNS) are generated either naturally in living cells or due to some biological dysfunction such as stress. These compounds have important roles in cell signaling but high amount of these compounds are harmful to the cells and their major components including DNA, enzymes, cell membrane lipids and proteins that play an important role in the development of diseases such as cancer and other disorders [6,7]. Antioxidants are compounds that may prevent from the free radical damages in biological systems. Among antioxidants, butylated hydroxyanisole (BHA) and butylated hydroxytoluene (BHT) as synthetic antioxidants are used as additives in foods but they have toxic and carcinogenic effects [8]. Studies focuses on antioxidant agents that can protect cell components from oxidative damage without harmful side effects [9]. Spiro compounds have also been recently used as antioxidants [10,11]. Today most of the microbes showed resistance to classical antibiotics [12,13] and the discovery of new compounds with novel mechanisms is a matter of urgency [14,15]. Recently, spiro compounds used as antimicrobial agents in the agricultural and industrial fields [16,17]. The tetrahydrobenzo[b]pyrans are an important calss of the heterocyclic compounds. These ring systems have been subjected of various studies and successfuly applied as anti-coagulant, diuretic, spasmolytic, anti-cancer, and anti-anaphylactic [18]. Also, these compunds posess the Physical properties and they can be widely used as photoactive materials [19]. Moreover, indenoquinoxalines exhibite different pharmological activity such as anti metabolism and antitubercular [20] and also spirooxindols are the core of a large pharmaceutical and natural alkaloids (Fig. 1 ) [21–25]. Ionic liquids have been considered as eco-friendly solvents, catalysts, and reagents in organic transformation becuase of their unique properties, including low volatility, non-flammability, high thermal stability, negligible vapor pressure and the their ability to dissolve of various materials [26–34]. Among them, Brønsted acidic ionic liquids, with useful characteristics of both solid acids and mineral liquid acids, have been prepared to replace traditional mineral liquid acids, such as sulfuric acid and hydrochloric acid, in chemical procedures [35–53]. Having above facts, we have designed acetic acid functionalized poly(4-vinylpyridinium) bromide (APVPB) (Fig. 2 ) as new, highly efficient and reusable catalyst for the preparation of 2-aminospiro[indoline-3,4ʹpyran]-2-one and spiro[indeno[1,2-b]quinoxaline-11,4-pyran]-2ʹ-amine derivatives by the multi-component condensation reaction of various carbonyl compounds (A) and α-methylen carbonyl compounds (B) as an activated carbonyl compound and malononitrile in water under reflux conditions (Scheme 1 ). Also, we tried to synthesize some new spiro-compounds with potential antimicrobial or antioxidant activities. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials All chemicals were purchased from Merck or Fluka Chemical Companies. The known products were identified by comparison of their melting points and spectral data with those reported in the literature. Progress of the reactions was monitored by TLC using silica gel SIL G/UV 254 plates. The 1H NMR (400 or 300MHz) and 13C NMR (100 or 75MHz) were recorded on a Bruker Avance DPX FT-NMR spectrometer (δ in ppm). Melting points were recorded on a Büchi B-545 apparatus in open capillary tubes. Differential thermal gravimetric (DTG) were analysed by a Perkin Elmer (Model: Pyris 1). TG/DTG analysis (25 to 600°C, temperature increase rate of 10°Cmin−1, nitrogen atmosphere).The structure of synthesized materials was determined by an X-ray diffractometer (Italstructure ADP2000 XRD diffractometer) at ambient temperature. 2.2 Catalyst preparation A mixture of bromoacetic acid (1.39g, 10mmol), sulfuric acid (2ml, 98%) and ethanol (10ml, 98%) in a 50mL round-bottomed flask connected to a reflux condenser, was stirred for 24h under reflux conditions. Then the mixture was washed with distilled water (3×15ml) to obtain 1.42g of an oily ethyl bromoacetate with 85% yield. In the next step mixture of ethyl bromoacetate (1.67g, 10mmol), was added to a suspension of powdered poly(4-vinylpyridine) (1.05g) [poly(4-vinylpyridine) cross-linked with 2% DVB ∼60mesh, MW: 60,000; Fluka Chemica] in over a period of 5min. Then, diethyl ether (30ml) was added to desire product in a round-bottomed flask (50ml) connected to a reflux condenser and stirred for 24h under reflux conditions. After removing solvent the residue was triturated with diethyl ether (3×15ml), and dried at 50°C for 1h. Afterwards, hydrobromic acid (1ml, 48%) and water (2ml) was added to reaction mixture and stirred for 2h under reflux conditions. The solvent was removed and the obtained product was triturated with diethyl ether (3×15ml) and dried under powerful vacuum at 50°C. Finally, acetic acid functionalized poly(4-vinylpyridinum) bromide (APVPB) was obtained as a white powder. 2.3 General procedure for the synthesis spiro[indeno[1,2-b]quinoxaline-11,4ʹ-pyran]-2ʹ-aminederivatives: Ninhydrin (1mmol), 1,2-diaminobenzenes (1mmol), and APVPB (10mg) were added in a 25-mL round-bottomed flask contained H2O (15ml) and connected to a reflux condenser for 10min, Then, alkylmalonates (1mmol) and malononitril (1mmol) were added to the reaction mixture. The mixture was stirred under reflux conditions for the appropriate time. Afterwards, the reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature and was allowed to attain at 25°C for about 1h. Then, the solvent was removed under vacuum and the prepared solid was collected by filtration. The mentioned solied was washed with ethanol and diethyl ether (2×20ml) and dried to remove starting materials. Finally, acetone (10ml) was added, stirred and refluxed for 3min. Then, the resulting mixture was centrifuged for the separation of the catalyst from the pure product (the product was soluble in warm acetone and the catalyst was insoluble in this solvent). 2.4 General procedure for the synthesis 2ʹ-aminospiro[indoline-3,4ʹ-pyran]-2-one derivatives: Isatin (1mmol), alkylmalonates (1mmol), malononitril (1mmol) and APVPB (10mg) were added in a 25-mL round-bottomed flask contained H2O (15ml) and connected to a reflux condenser. The reaction mixture was stirred under reflux conditions for the appropriate time. Afterwards, the reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature and was allowed to attain at 25°C for 1h. Then, the solvent was removed under vacuum. Then, the prepared solid was collected by filtration and washed with ethanol and diethylether (2×15ml) and dried to remove starting materials. Finally, acetone (10ml) was added, stirred and refluxed for 3min. Then, the resulting mixture was centrifuged for the separation of the catalyst from the pure product (the product was soluble in warm acetone and the catalyst was insoluble in this solvent). 3 Biological activity 3.1 Antioxidant capacity 3.1.1 Method A The DPPH radical scavenging activity of the spiro-pyran derivatives were evaluated according to Mensor et al. [54]. Initially, 2.5ml of the samples at concentration of 0.2 to 1mg/ml were prepared in methanol and mixed with 1ml of 0.3mM DPPH that was dissolved in methanol. The reaction mixture was incubated in the dark for 30min at 25°C. Bleaching of DPPH was read at 517nm against a blank (methanol) using the UV–vis spectrophotometer. The inhibition in percent for each concentration was calculated according to the following formula: DPPH free radical scavenging (%)=[1− (As − Ab)/Ac]×100 where, As is absorbance of the reaction mixture containing 2.5ml of samples+1ml of DPPH, Ab is absorbance of the reaction mixture containing 2.5ml of samples+1ml methanol and Ac is absorbance of control sample containing 1ml of DPPH+2.5ml methanol. Also IC50 value, which represented the concentration of the sample that caused 50% inhibition, was determined. Tests were carried out in triplicate and ascorbic acid was used as a positive control. 3.1.2 Method B Blood samples were obtained from rats by cardiac puncture and collected in falcon tubes. Then, they were immediately centrifuged at 4000rpm for 10min to obtain plasma. 2.4ml of the samples (1mg/ml) were mixed with 1ml of 0.3mM DPPH dissolved in methanol. The DPPH radical scavenging activity of the samples was evaluated according to method A and above formula. Where, As is absorbance of the reaction mixture containing 2.4ml of samples (plasma+spiro-pyran or plasma without spiro-pyran and or spiro-pyran without plasma) + 1ml of DPPH, Ab is absorbance of the reaction mixture containing 2.4ml of samples+ 1ml methanol and Ac is absorbance of control sample containing 1ml of DPPH+2.4ml methanol. 3.2 Antifungal activity Antifungal activity of spiro-pyran derivatives was in vitro assessed against Fusarium oxysporum cultivated in Potatoes Dextrose Agar (PDA) medium. Some spiro-pyran derivative samples (C1, C13 and C19) were added to cultivation medium at two concentrations (500 and 1000ppm). In order to make the control groups, double distilled water and DMSO were added to the plates. After a 7-days incubation of fungus on culture medium containing samples, radial growth of fungal mycelium was recorded. The following formula was used for calculation of the inhibition rate (%): Inhibition rate (%)=(R-r/R)×100 where, R is the radial growth of fungal mycelia on the control plate and r is the radial growth of fungal mycelia on the plate treated with spiro-pyran derivatives. All data are the average of triplicate analyses. 3.3 Statistical analysis Statistical analysis of variance was performed using Student’s t-test by SPSS program and p value<0.05 was regarded as significant. Data are expressed as means±standard deviation. 4 Results and discussion Acetic acid functionalized poly(4-vinylpyridinum) bromide (APVPB) was prepared in three steps. Initially, bromo ethylacetate was prepared by the reaction of bromoacetic acid with sulfuric acid I. In the second step, bromo ethylacetate reacted with poly(4-vinylpyridine) in diethyl ether under reflux conditions for 24h to afford II. Afterwards, hydrobromic acid (1ml, 48%) and water (2ml) was added to reaction mixture and stirred for 2h under reflux conditions to hydrolyze and prepare acetic acid functionalized poly(4-vinylpyridinum) bromide (APVPB) (Scheme 2 ). The structure of APVPB was identified by IR, XRD, TG, DTG, EDX, as well as SEM analysis. The IR spectrum of the catalyst showed a broad peak at 2700–3600cm−1 which could be corresponded to OH stretching of COOH group and the peak observed at 1729cm−1 corresponds to stretching mode of CO bond of this group. The IR spectrum of APVPB in comparison with poly (4-vinylpyridine) was shown in Fig. 3 . The XRD pattern of the catalyst (APVPB) was studied and exhibited a broadened pattern due to its non-crystalline nature at 2θ=14–35° (Fig. 4 ). Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of APVPB was also investigated. The corresponding diagrams are displayed in Fig. 5 . The thermal gravimetric (TG) and differential thermal gravimetric (DTG) of the catalyst showed weight losses in two step. Acetic acid functionalized poly(4-vinylpyridinum) bromide (APVPB) was decomposed after 231°C in two step. This study clearly showed that APVPB can be used at temperatures up to 231°C. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) of desired catalyst (APVPB) showed the existance of the expected elements in the structure of the catalyst, namely carbon, oxygen, nitrogen and bromine (Fig. 6 ). Accordingly, the structure of the catalyst was completely confirmed by EDX analyze. In another investigation, the SEM micrograph of the catalyst showed that the particles have not completely agglomerated. The particles of the catalyst were observed in nano scales (Fig. 7 ). After the preparation and characterization of the catalyst, the catalytic application of APVPB was investigated on the synthesis of spiropyran derivatives. To optimize the reaction conditions, as a model reaction, the condensation between isatin (1mmol), dimedon(1mmol) and malononitrile (1mmol) was studied in the presence of different amounts of APVPB under reflux conditions. The reaction was efficiently performed using 10mg of the catalyst under reflux condition to give the desired product in high yield within short reaction times. In the next step, the model reaction was examined in the persence of several solvents using 10mg of APVPB under reflux conditions. As Table 1 , indicates that water was the best solvent in this reaction (Table 1, entry 2). Although, the reaction was studied in the absence of solvent, but the yield of product was very low (Table 1, entry 1). To assess the efficacy and generality of APVPB in the preparation of 2-aminospiro[indoline-3,4ʹpyran]-2-one and spiro[indeno[1,2-b]quinoxaline-11,4-pyran]-2ʹ-amine derivatives, various α-methylencarbonyl compounds as an activated carbonyl compound (B) were reacted with carbonyl compounds (A) and malononitrile in water under reflux conditions to afford the corresponding products in high yields and short reaction times. The results are depicted in Tables 2, 3 and 4 . In a proposed mechanism [17b], at first, ninhydrin and 1,2-phenylenediamine reacted together to give the corresponding indenoquinoxaline A in the presence of APVPB (Scheme 3 ). Indenoquinoxaline and isatin derivatives as carbonyl compounds A (I), which is activated by APVPB, was reacted with malononitrile to furnish intermediate II after removing of one molecule of H2O. Methylen carbonyl compounds (B) is converted to enol form after tautomerisation and attacked to cyanoolefincompound (II), as a Michael acceptor, to give III. Finally, cyclocondensation reaction of III prepared IV, which is converted to the corresponding product. The recyclability of APVPB was examined upon the condensation reaction of isatin (1mmol), dimedon (1mmol) and malononitrile (1mmol). After the completion of the reaction, the reaction mixture was filtered and the solvent of the filtrate (H2O) was removed under reduced pressure. The reaction mixture was washed with ethanol and diethyl ether (2×20ml) and dried to remove starting materials. Afterwards, acetone was added, stirred and refluxed for 3min. Then, the mixture prouct and catalyst was centrifuged for the separation of the catalyst from the product. The remained catalyst was washed with warm aceton (10ml) and dried to reuse for the next run. Catalytic activity of APVPB was restored within the limits of the experimental errors for 4 successive recycle runs (Fig. 8 ). 5 Biological activity 5.1 Antioxidant capacity Antioxidants are as a health-protection factor in foods and scientific evidence suggests that these compounds are very important due to their role in reducing the risk of chronic diseases such as cancer and inflammation diseases [61]. Antioxidants may act as scavenger, reducing, quencher agents and/or can strongly interact with proteins and inhibit activity of some enzymes involved in ROS and RNS generation, such as various cytochrome P450 isoforms, lipoxygenases, cyclooxygenase, xanthine oxidase and also activators of cellular antioxidant enzymes to prevent from the free radical damages in biological systems [62–64]. Many studies focus on new antioxidant agents without harmful side effects. Among new compounds, spiro compounds have also been recently used as antioxidants [65–67]. In the presented research, DPPH free radical scavenging activity of the new spiro-pyran derivatives was determined (Table 5 and 2 and Fig. 9 ). Our results showed that most of the synthesized spiro-pyranderivatives showed excellent dose-dependent (0.2–1mg/ml) antiradical properties (24.59–64.07%) (Table 5). Antioxidant activity is reflected in a lower IC50value. Ascorbic acid (VitaminC) as a synthetic antioxidant represented lower IC50 value (IC50; 0.145±0.009mg/ml) than those of the most compounds studied here (IC50; 0.161±0.009 to 1.509±0.007mg/ml), (Fig. 9). Generally, most of the free radicals generated are scavenged by endogenous defense system such as catalase, superoxide dismutase and peroxidase-glutathione system [68]. Antiradical properties of synthesized spiro-pyran derivatives (C1, C15 and C33) increased by adding blood plasma of rats (53.16±2.6% to 76.00±2.5%) and were more compared to plasma as negative control (22.61±2.3%). However, ascorbic acid as a positive control (82.04±1.2%) showed the most antiradical activity (Table 6 ). 5.2 Antifungal activity Many crops throughout the world are host plants for Fusarium species causing soil-borne diseases of great economic importance. F. oxysporum is one of the major soil-borne pathogens that attacks its host by entering through the root and grows in the plant xylem, eventually blocking the vascular system and causes severe losses of crop and ultimately death of the plants of great economic importance [69,70]. The inhibition zone values were determined for some random selected compounds synthesized here (C1, C13, and C19) against F. oxysporum (Table 7 ). In this research, it was observed that DMSO as negative control had no activity against F. oxysporum, but samples showed excellent antifungal activity (Table 7). Most of old synthetic fungicides usually are difficult to degrade and are toxic to humans. Hence, the examined samples may be used to treat plant diseases caused by F. oxysporum and also to increase resistance in a wide variety of crop plants. 6 Conclusion In summary, we have synthesized acetic acid functionalized poly(4-vinylpyridinum) bromide (APVPB) as type of Bronsted acidic catalyst and fully characterized by several techniques including fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), X-ray diffraction (XRD), thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA), differential thermal gravimetric (DTG), scanning electron microscope (SEM), and energy dispersive X-ray analysis (EDX). APVPB was successfully tested as a reusable, stable, general and heterogeneous catalyst for the synthesis of 2-aminospiro[indoline-3,4ʹpyran]-2-one and spiro[indeno[1,2-b]quinoxaline-11,4-pyran]-2ʹ-amine derivatives via four-component or one-pot three-component condensation reaction of various carbonyl compounds (1–3) and α-methylencarbonyl compounds (4a–e) and malononitrile in water under reflux conditions. Short reaction times, solvent-free and mild reaction conditions and reusability of catalyst are some advantages of this work. Also, results from present study clearly demonstrated that studied compounds exhibit biological properties that might be helpful in preventing the progress of development of novel therapeutic agents. coredata.dc:description: Acetic acid functionalized poly(4-vinylpyridinium) bromide (APVPB), as a new and heterogeneous catalyst, was designed and successfully tested on the synthesis of 2-aminospiro[indoline-3,4ʹpyran]-2-one and spiro[indeno[1,2-b]quinoxaline-11,4-pyran]-2ʹ-amine derivatives. Also, infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA), differential thermal gravimetric (DTG), scanning electron microscope (SEM), X-ray diffraction analysis (XRD) and energy dispersive X-ray analysis (EDX) of the catalyst has been studied in the presented work. The prepared spiro-pyrans were solved in DMSO and subjected to antioxidant activity screening by DPPH free radical scavenging assay and antifungal activity against Fusarium oxysporum. Results showed that the synthesized spiro-pyran possess strong antioxidant activity (IC50; 0.161±0.009 to 1.509±0.007mg/ml) and also good inhibition activity against Fusarium oxysporum (65.8±1.4% to 88.3±2.2% at 500 ppm concentration and 89.2±3.2% to 100±0.0% at 1000ppm concentration). For their biological activities, the prepared spiro-pyran compounds may be suggested to apply as alternative systems in medicine and agriculture.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis and characterization of acetic acid functionalized poly (4-vinylpyridinium) salt as new catalyst for the synthesis of spiropyran derivatives and their biological activity
